narrative: Contrary to the image of a sink full of soapy water, a dishwasher acts more like a mechanical rainstorm. It combines high heat, chemical detergents, and pressurized spray arms to strip food away from dishes, filtering and recirculating a small amount of water to clean efficiently before pumping it all away.

slides.title: It's Not a Bathtub
slides.content: Many believe dishwashers fill completely with water, but they actually use a surprisingly small amount. The machine is a watertight seal that pools a shallow layer of water at the bottom, which is then continuously recycled throughout the wash cycle.
slides.imagePrompt: A cross-section 3D render of a dishwasher in operation, showing a low water level at the very bottom basin only, contrasting with the dry air space in the rest of the machine where the racks are.

slides.title: The Heating Element
slides.content: Cold water enters through an intake valve, but it needs to be much hotter to melt grease and kill bacteria. A metal heating element at the bottom, often called a calrod, heats the water to temperatures between 130째F and 150째F (55째C - 65째C).
slides.imagePrompt: Close-up hyper-realistic illustration of a metal heating coil (calrod) at the bottom of a dishwasher basin, glowing slightly red under the water to indicate heat, with bubbles forming.

slides.title: The Pump and Spray Arms
slides.content: An electric pump forces the hot water up into hollow spray arms located beneath the racks. The pressure of the water shooting out of angled jets causes the arms to rotate, blasting dishes from every angle.
slides.imagePrompt: A schematic animation style frame showing the internal plumbing, highlighting the pump pushing water into the spray arms.
slides.videoPrompt: A 3D animation showing water rushing through hollow plastic arms, shooting out of angled jets, causing the arms to spin rapidly and spray water upwards.

slides.title: The Wash Cycle
slides.content: Once the dishes are wet, the detergent dispenser opens, mixing soap with the circulating water. This chemical mix breaks down proteins and grease, while a filter at the bottom traps large food particles to keep the water clean enough to reuse.
slides.imagePrompt: A split-level view showing the detergent dispenser door opening on the door panel and soapy water cascading over plates, with a mesh filter visible at the bottom trapping food bits.

slides.title: Rinsing and Draining
slides.content: After the cleaning cycle, the dirty water is pumped out through a drain hose into your kitchen's plumbing. Fresh, clean water enters for a final rinse to wash away any remaining detergent or debris, ensuring the dishes are spotless.
slides.imagePrompt: Diagram showing dirty brown water exiting through a drain hose on the left, while crystal clear blue water enters through the intake valve on the right.

slides.title: The Drying Phase
slides.content: To finish the job, the heating element turns on again to heat the air inside the tub. This evaporates the remaining water droplets on the dishes, or in some modern models, a fan circulates the moist air out of the machine.
slides.imagePrompt: Inside view of a dishwasher with clean sparkling dishes, visible steam rising from them, and the heating element glowing at the bottom, representing the drying phase.
